definitions.text: the basic unit of money in Brazil; equal to 100 centavos
an old small silver Spanish coin
being or occurring in fact or actuality; having verified existence; not illusory; ; ; ; ; ; - Longfellow
examples: a film based on real life
Life is real! Life is earnest!

definitions.text: no less than what is stated; worthy of the name
examples: meat and potatoes--I call that a real meal
it's time he had a real job
it's no penny-ante job--he's making real money
statistics demonstrate that poverty and unemployment are very real problems
to the man sleeping regularly in doorways homelessness is real

definitions.text: capable of being treated as fact
examples: his brief time as Prime Minister brought few real benefits to the poor

definitions.text: being or reflecting the essential or genuine character of something; ; - G.K.Chesterton
examples: a literal solitude like a desert

definitions.text: of, relating to, or representing an amount that is corrected for inflation
having substance or capable of being treated as fact; not imaginary; ; ; - Shakespeare
examples: a mere dream, neither substantial nor practical
real property consists of land and buildings
perceptual error...has a surprising resemblance to veridical perception

definitions.text: used as intensifiers; `real' is sometimes used informally for `really'; `rattling' is informal
